title: R43453
content: The renewable electricity PTC is a tax credit for electricity generated using qualified energy resources, sold to an unrelated person. The credit can be claimed for 10 years once a qualifying facility is in service. The maximum credit amount for 2017 and 2018 is 2.4 cents per kWh, adjusted annually for inflation. Wind, closed-loop biomass, and geothermal energy qualify for the maximum credit amount. The renewable electricity PTC offers a tax credit of 2.4 cents per kWh for qualified energy resources. Wind, closed-loop biomass, and geothermal energy qualify for the maximum credit amount, while other technologies receive a reduced credit. Nonwind facilities starting construction before January 1, 2018, may also qualify for the PTC. Under current law, nonwind facilities starting construction before January 1, 2018, may qualify for a reduced credit amount. The credit for wind facilities is available for those starting construction before January 1, 2020, with reductions based on the year of construction. The PTC expiration date used to be a placed-in-service deadline before 2013. The Production Tax Credit (PTC) is reduced by 40% for facilities starting construction in 2018 and by 60% for facilities starting construction in 2019. The PTC amount may phase out once electricity market prices exceed threshold levels, but this has not happened yet. The PTC is not likely to be phased out under current law. In the past, the ability to claim the PTC was also limited by the corporate alternative minimum tax. The Production Tax Credit (PTC) has not been phased out despite market prices not exceeding threshold levels. Before 2018, the PTC was limited by the corporate alternative minimum tax (AMT), which was eliminated in the 2017 tax revision. The corporate AMT was eliminated in the 2017 tax revision, allowing unused credits to offset future tax liability. PTC-eligible taxpayers had the option of claiming the energy investment tax credit or an ARRA Section 1603 grant for property placed in service from 2009 to 2011. Additionally, there are production tax credits for Indian coal and refined products. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) Section 1603 grant was available for properties placed in service during 2009, 2010, or 2011. Production tax credits are also available for Indian coal and refined coal, with a base rate of $2.00 per ton for Indian coal. Credits are not available for coal produced after 2017. The production tax credits for Indian coal and refined coal have specific base rates and inflation adjustments. Credits are not available for coal produced after 2017. Refined coal facilities must have been placed in service before January 1, 2012, to qualify for credits, with a 10-year production period allowed. The Production Tax Credit (PTC) was enacted in 1992 to promote renewable energy sources, and its extension in 1999 was to further develop environmentally friendly renewable power. The Production Tax Credit (PTC) was extended in 1999 to promote renewable energy sources and drive investment in the wind industry. Recent extensions reflect a belief that the PTC contributes to the development of renewable energy infrastructure, aligning with environmental and energy policy goals. Further extension may lead to additional investment and growth in wind infrastructure, although potential is limited in some cases. The Production Tax Credit (PTC) drives investment and growth in the wind industry, aligning with environmental goals. Further extension may lead to more investment, but short-term extensions have limitations. Retroactive extensions provide windfall benefits to taxpayers. The PTC has increased renewable electricity use, but its impact on reducing greenhouse gas emissions is mixed. Research shows that removing tax credits for renewable electricity would result in a small increase in power-sector emissions. Renewable energy tax credit extensions contribute to reduced emissions, especially with low natural gas prices. Government intervention in energy markets is often justified by the presence of externalities. The National Renewable Energy Laboratory found that tax credits for wind and solar help reduce emissions, especially when natural gas prices are low. Government intervention in energy markets is often necessary due to externalities like pollution, which result in market failures. Tax subsidies for clean energy resources are one policy option for addressing inefficiencies and market failures in the energy sector. However, subsidies may not be the most efficient way to achieve the policy objective as they can encourage energy consumption, counter energy conservation initiatives, and offset emissions reductions. Tax subsidies in the energy sector may not be the most efficient way to achieve policy objectives. They reduce energy costs, encourage consumption, counter conservation efforts, and offset emissions reductions. Additionally, they may not provide equal incentives for all emission reduction alternatives and can reduce tax revenues, leading to economic inefficiency. A more direct and economically efficient approach is needed to address pollution and environmental concerns in the energy sector. Tax subsidies in the energy sector reduce tax revenues and economic efficiency. A more efficient approach would be a direct tax on pollution, like a carbon tax, which could generate revenues to offset other taxes and address environmental concerns. This approach is technology neutral and avoids the need for Congress to select technologies to subsidize. A carbon tax approach is more efficient than tax incentives for delivering federal financial support to renewable energy developers and investors. Tax equity financing arrangements with outside investors reduce direct federal financial support to the renewable energy sector. The use of tax equity investors reduces federal financial support for renewable energy, incentivizing production over investment. Interaction with other policies like Renewable Portfolio Standards is a key consideration. The PTC, along with other renewable energy policies, supports the development of renewable electricity resources. The proposal aimed to eliminate the PTC inflation adjustment factor, reducing the value of the PTC for renewable electricity to 1.5 cents per kWh for all eligible properties within the 10-year window. This would have affected facilities that received a 2.3 cent per kWh PTC in 2014 and were still within their 10-year PTC window in 2015. President Obama's FY2017 budget proposed a permanent extension of the PTC, making it refundable and adding solar facilities as qualifying property. Solar property eligible for the residential energy efficient property credit would also qualify. The PTC and ITC for renewable energy would be made permanent, with solar facilities added as qualifying property. Renewable electricity consumed by the producer could qualify for tax credits, and solar property eligible for the residential energy efficient property credit would also qualify.
